channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Italy’s Populists Move Closer to Power, With Little-Known Pick for Prime Minister
item.media:description: Giuseppe Conte in Rome, before the Italian elections this spring.
item.description: Giuseppe Conte, a civil law professor with a long resume, must still be approved. But his main qualification may be his willingness to do the bidding of his backers.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: If War Comes? Stock Up on Tortillas and Wet Wipes, Sweden Suggests
item.media:description: Christina Andersson and Dan Eliasson of the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency presented the brochure “If Crisis or War Comes” in Stockholm on Monday.
item.description: The country released a revised handbook titled “If Crisis or War Comes,” its first such update since the Cold War era.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Ireland, Enthusiastic About Gay Rights, Frets Over Abortion
item.media:description: An anti-abortion rally in Dublin this month. Polls for the referendum on Friday have narrowed so tightly that “yes” and “no” campaigners are not able to predict a victory.
item.description: While the once-profound influence of the Catholic Church has faded, abortion is an exception, leaving the results of the coming referendum unpredictable.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Ken Livingstone Quits U.K. Labour Party in Anti-Semitism Dispute
item.media:description: Ken Livingstone speaking to reporters in London in April 2016. He had made remarks suggesting that Hitler had at one point supported Zionism.
item.description: The former London mayor resigned more than two years after being suspended in a dispute that was an embarrassment to the party leadership.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Venice Journal: A Chance to Spend 99-Plus Years in Venice (in the Afterlife)
item.media:description: The San Michele cemetery in Venice is the resting place of numerous celebrities as well as Venetians of all classes.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Even if you can’t afford a palazzo on the Grand Canal, you might be able to bid for a plot in the cemetery of San Michele.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Syria Regains Control of Damascus, After Seven Years of Fighting
item.media:description: Syrian government forces on a destroyed street in the Hajar al-Aswad area on the southern outskirts of Damascus on Monday.
item.description: With the last of 1,600 militants departing from the Palestinian camp of Yarmouk, fighting around the capital is over. Peace, though, remains elusive.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: U.K. Lawmakers Say Dirty Russian Money Is Still Flowing to London
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy on the exclusive avenue of Kensington Palace Gardens in March in London.
item.description: Despite the government’s tough talk, a hard-hitting parliamentary report says it is business as usual for Russian oligarchs in the city’s financial “laundromat.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: 75-Year-Old Mayor Is Attacked in Greece, and Nationalists Rejoice
item.media:description: The mayor of Thessaloniki, Yiannis Boutaris, left, was attacked during a public gathering in the northern Greek city on Saturday.
item.description: Yiannis Boutaris, known for his outspoken views against far-right violence and racism, was assaulted at a ceremony commemorating victims of a World War I genocide.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: ‘God Made You This Way,’ Pope Is Said to Have Told Gay Man
item.description: A Chilean survivor of sexual abuse said that during his private meeting with Pope Francis, the pontiff embraced him for who he was.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Is Facebook Different From The National Enquirer? An Irish Lawyer Thinks Not
item.media:description: “I say to Facebook, ‘What is the difference between you and a national newspaper being responsible for the letters they publish on their letters page? Why do you have to be treated differently?” said the Irish lawyer Paul Tweed.
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Paul Tweed attracted star clients by suing publishers in Belfast, London and Dublin. He plans to hold the social media giants to the same standards.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Australian Archbishop Found Guilty of Sexual Abuse Cover-Up
item.media:description: Archbishop Philip Wilson, center, arriving at a courthouse in Newcastle, Australia, on Tuesday. He was convicted of covering up abuse by a priest in the state of New South Wales in the 1970s.
item.media:credit: Peter Lorimer/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: Archbishop Philip Wilson became the highest-ranking Catholic official to be convicted of concealing child sexual abuse. He faces two years in prison.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: How to Win an Election in Venezuela: Control the Food
item.description: Subsidized eggs and frozen chickens may help to explain why President Nicolás Maduro stayed in power. Our correspondents followed his supporters as they enticed undernourished citizens to vote for Mr. Maduro in exchange for food.

item.title: Obama, Gina Haspel, Texas: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: As Trump Adds Sanctions on Venezuela, Its Neighbors Reject Election Result
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, center, giving a victory wave in Caracas after the election results were announced on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: A group of mainly Latin American nations said the vote had not “met with the international standards of a democratic, free, just and transparent electoral process.”
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Dozens Die in Karachi from Relentless Heat
item.media:description: A volunteer sprays water on people to keep them cool as temperatures reached 44 degrees Celsius (111.2 degrees Fahrenheit) in Karachi, Pakistan, on Monday.
item.description: The 15 million residents of Karachi, the Pakistani port city known as the concrete jungle, are enduring a heat wave with little relief in sight.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: They Spoke Spanish in a Montana Store. Then a Border Agent Asked for Their IDs.
item.media:description: A Border Patrol agent stopped a pair of friends who were speaking Spanish on Wednesday inside a convenience store in Havre, Mont.
item.description: The agent told the two U.S. citizens: “It has to do with you guys speaking Spanish in the store in a state where it’s predominantly English-speaking.”
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Global Health: For First Time, W.H.O. Names Some Lab Tests ‘Essential’
item.media:description: Taking blood for an H.I.V. test at a mobile clinic in KwaZulu Natal, South Africa. The World Health Organization has recommended 113 diagnostic tests it considers essential to every health care system in the world.
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Forty years after creating its “essential medicines” list, which revolutionized the struggle to get drugs to the poor, the agency tackles diagnostics.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Regional Australia, Part 2 of 2: Australia’s Immigration Solution: Small-Town Living
item.media:description: Children playing behind St. Patrick's Catholic School in Pyramid Hill, a small town in Australia being revived through immigration.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: How rural Australia opened itself to the world and became a model of integration and revival.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: In Hard-Line Speech, Pompeo Criticizes Iran’s Behavior
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo delivered a remarkably hard-line speech about Iran, offering no concessions to European leaders who want to do business with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Trump’s Charm and Threats May Not Be Working on China. Here’s Why.
item.media:description: On Monday, President Trump promoted his administration’s trade talks with China as a success, saying on Twitter that they would lead China to buy more American agricultural goods.
item.description: President Trump threatened tariffs on $150 billion in goods, then tried conciliation. Beijing’s response either way: Rebuff the offers and avoid specific pledges.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: British Woman Serving 5-Year Sentence in Iran Faces New Charges
item.media:description: Richard Ratcliffe, the husband of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, held a photograph of the couple and Gabriella, their daughter, in London last month.
item.media:credit: John Stillwell/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe could have more time tacked on to her conviction for spying, possibly because of a gaffe by Boris Johnson, the British foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: U.K. Unlikely to Block Comcast’s Proposed Sky Takeover, Minister Says
item.media:description: Sky holds lucrative broadcast rights for English Premier League soccer games, as well as other professional sports tournaments, and has an online streaming service.
item.description: The decision by Britain’s culture secretary is the latest twist in a takeover battle between Comcast and Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox for control of the British satellite broadcaster.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: U.K. Court Dismisses Charges Over Qatar Fund-Raising by Barclays
item.media:description: A British court has dismissed charges against Barclays over a fund-raising round during the 2008 financial crisis that gave it much-needed financial infusions without a government bailout.
item.description: The case was the first in the country against a bank for actions during the global financial crisis, and the decision is a blow to British regulators.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Death of Japanese Climber on Everest Raises Toll This Month to 3
item.media:description: The body of the Japanese climber Nobukazu Kuriki was airlifted on Monday to Kathmandu, the Nepalese capital, for an autopsy to ascertain the exact cause of his death.
item.media:credit: Ang Tashi Sherpa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Officials said Nobukazu Kuriki, who had tried to reach the summit seven other times, died after he slipped and fell near Camp Three.
item.dc:creator: RAJNEESH BHANDARI

item.title: In China, Photo of Trade Talks Embodies ‘Young’ Country Passing Aging U.S.
item.description: Social media users noticed a distinct age gap between the Chinese delegates and the American lawmakers who met them in Washington.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Grenfell Tower Inquiry Opens in London With Focus on Victims
item.media:description: The remains of Grenfell Tower in London, where a fire last year led to the deaths of 72 people.
item.description: The first nine days of the public investigation are to be devoted to tributes to the dead by friends and families, reflecting the powerful emotions at play.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Venezuela Election Won by Maduro Amid Widespread Disillusionment
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela giving a victory speech in Caracas on Sunday night. He made scant mention of the low turnout, telling a cheering crowd, “And here we are again, victorious!”
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Nicolás Maduro won a second term as president of Venezuela, in a contest that critics said was heavily rigged in his favor and which many voters shunned.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Palestinian President, Mahmoud Abbas, Reported Hospitalized
item.media:description: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, speaking at his headquarters in the West Bank town of Ramallah last week.
item.description: Palestinian officials and doctors gave conflicting accounts of the condition of Mr. Abbas, who is 82.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Trump Grappling With Risks of Proceeding With North Korea Meeting
item.media:description: President Trump with President Moon Jae-in of South Korea in New York last year. Mr. Trump is scheduled to meet with Mr. Moon on Tuesday ahead of his scheduled summit meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in Singapore next month.
item.description: President Trump was surprised and angered by a statement issued by the North’s chief nuclear negotiator, who declared that the country would not swap its nuclear weapons capability for economic aid.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: U.K. Visa for Roman Abramovich, Russian Billionaire, Is Delayed
item.media:description: The Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, left.
item.description: Mr. Abramovich, owner of Chelsea, missed a high-profile soccer match after his visa expired. It’s unclear if his troubles are a bureaucratic hiccup or if Britain is clamping down.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Once Hated by U.S. and Tied to Iran, Is Sadr Now ‘Face of Reform’ in Iraq?
item.media:description: The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on his way to vote in the parliamentary election in Najaf, Iraq, on May 12.
item.description: Moktada al-Sadr, the upset winner of Iraq’s election, has undergone a reinvention, from a militant Shiite to an anticorruption champion whose “Iraq First” message appeals across religious divides.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET COKER

item.title: A Royal Window Into a Newly Minted Duchess
item.media:description: A crowd gathered to watch the royal wedding on a big screen at the National Maritime Museum in London on Saturday. But there were still walkers and sunbathers in the park nearby.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: “I am proud to be a woman and a feminist,” says the Duchess of Sussex, a.k.a. the American-born Meghan Markle, who married Prince Harry.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Over 10,000 Moroccans Protest U.S. Embassy Move to Jerusalem
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters at a demonstration organized by a Moroccan Islamist association in Casablanca on Sunday.
item.description: Chanting “death to Israel,” marchers carried Palestinian flags and placards that called Jerusalem “Palestine’s eternal capital.”
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The Mafia Reporter With a Police Escort (and the 200 Journalists Like Him)
item.media:description: Paolo Borrometi is one of nearly 200 journalists in Italy who live under police protection.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Paolo Borrometi is among scores of Italian journalists under police protection after their reporting angered crime figures. “That doesn’t happen in other countries,” says a press freedom advocate.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Pakistan Has Just One New Polio Case, but Isn’t Declaring Victory Yet
item.media:description: Gul Saima helping her 3-year-old son, Sayyad Karam, outside their home in Dukki, Pakistan. The boy was diagnosed with polio in April, the country’s only new case this year.
item.media:credit: Danial Shah for The New York Times
item.description: The country has come tantalizingly close to eradicating the virus in recent years, only to be foiled by instability, mistrust and attacks on vaccinators.
item.dc:creator: MEHER AHMAD

item.title: REgional Australia, PArt 1 of 2: A Booming Economy With a Tragic Price
item.media:description: The grave of James Guy at a cemetery in the Australian state of Victoria. Mr. Guy hanged himself on the dairy farm that he owned with his wife, Mary.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Australia is a breadbasket to the world and a globalization success story. So why are its farmers killing themselves?
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Itu Aba Journal: Island or Rock? Taiwan Defends Its Claim in South China Sea
item.media:description: Itu Aba is a small strip of land in the South China Sea occupied by Taiwan. Its name in Chinese is Taiping, which means peaceful or tranquil.
item.description: China and Taiwan share claims to the South China Sea, but a visit to Taiwan’s “island” shows how they diverge in exercising control.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Pope Francis Names 14 Choices for New Cardinals
item.media:description: Pope Francis told the crowd in St. Peter’s Square that the new cardinals’ countries of origin “express the universality of the church.”
item.description: Prelates based in Iraq and Pakistan, and the Vatican official in charge of aid for Rome’s homeless and poor, are among those to be elevated on June 29.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gunmen Attack Church in Russia’s Chechnya Region, Killing 3
item.media:description: The police outside the Archangel Michael Church in Grozny, Chechnya, site of an attack by gunmen on Saturday.
item.description: Four gunmen stormed a Russian Orthodox church in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya on Saturday, before being killed by security forces.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Israel and Evangelicals: New U.S. Embassy Signals a Growing Alliance
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and David M. Friedman, the American ambassador to Israel, at the dedication of the American Embassy in Jerusalem. “You’re running a country, you need friends,” Mr. Friedman said.
item.description: The opening of the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem marks the increasing importance of conservative Christians to Israel, at the risk of upsetting American Jews.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, ELIZABETH DIAS and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Meghan Markle Introduces the British Monarchy to the African-American Experience
item.description: Centuries of tradition seemed to peel away as Bishop Michael Curry spoke to the crowd of aristocrats in the cadence of the black American church.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: Congo Says 3 New Ebola Cases Confirmed in Large City
item.media:description: Health care workers wearing protective gear at a treatment center in Bikoro, Congo. The country’s latest Ebola outbreak has spread to a city of more than one million people.
item.description: Three new cases of the Ebola virus have been confirmed in a city of more than one million people, Congo’s health minister announced.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hand-Me-Down Plane That Crashed Reflects a Cuban Air Industry in Crisis
item.media:description: Rescuers searching through the wreckage of a Boeing 737 that crashed with more than 100 passengers on board near Havana on Friday.
item.description: The 39-year-old plane is a powerful symbol of the troubled aviation industry. As tourism surges, Cuba’s national airline struggles to buy planes and maintain its fleet.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Germany Acts to Tame Facebook, Learning From Its Own History of Hate
item.media:description: At a Facebook deletion center in Berlin, the agents, who work for a third-party firm, remove illegal hate speech from the social network.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: A country taps its past as it leads the way on one of the most pressing issues facing modern democracies: how to regulate the world’s biggest social network.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Modi Visits Kashmir and Is Met With a Strike
item.media:description: Indian paramilitary soldiers patrolling in Srinagar in Indian-controlled Kashmir, during Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit on Saturday.
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited the disputed region of Kashmir, where he was met by calls from separatists for a shutdown of the area.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Prince Harry and Meghan Markle Wed, a New Era Dawns
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle kissed on the steps of St. George’s Chapel after their wedding in Windsor, England, on Saturday.
item.description: An extraordinary ceremony with strong elements of African-American culture showed the couple’s determination to bring Britain’s royal family into the modern world.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: A Wedding Album for Harry and Meghan
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, after their wedding at St. George’s Chapel.
item.description: Scroll through the most memorable images from the big day.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: Surfacing: What This 76-Year-Old Man Can Teach About Healing
item.media:description: I Gusti Mangku Sasak, 76
item.description: “I never lock my door; if people show up at night, I will wake up,” said I Gusti Mangku Sasak, a holistic Usada Bali healer.
item.dc:creator: MALIN FEZEHAI
